posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.com: Before the addition of NPC Vendors you could hire and place on your homes, players used to crowd the city streets of Britain, Vesper and Trinsic to sell their wares to other players. Never before had a game world felt more "alive."

Dungeon crawling with semi-randomized layouts and loot. Weapon upgrading and evolving. One character gets a customizable robot to fight in, the other transforms into enemy monsters with set skills. You recruit townspeople to go live in towns you get to design and customize.

>>9525435
A few years ago I was watching random Game Center episodes, my parents and my brother were out of town so I went to my brother's bedroom intent on smoking some of his weed (I had smoked before). He had some sort of dust in a grinder thing (I have no clue about weed stuff other than just smoking it very occasionally).
I put some weed in the pipe with the dust and smoked, waited half an hour and nothing happened, figured I'd smoked too little and just left it at that, then went to take a shower. I was in the shower for a good half an hour before I realized I was finally high. All the lights hurt, and directly looking at one for a brief moment made my ears feel like I was getting hit with cymbals in the head. All I could do was fall on my bed, cover my face with a pillow and focus on Arino's voice until I felt well enough to get up and turn off the lights. GCCX stood there running with me all night, keeping me safe from my druggie demons.
Thank you Arino-san.

Dragon Ball NES - Challenging game that Arino has some laughs with, it's also kind of wacky.

Sonic the Hedgehog - He struggles more than I would have guessed, plus priceless interactions with the awkward Nakayama's debut.

Famicom Detective Club - Fun to see Arino play detective and do a pretty good job of sorting witnesses etc.

Legend of the River King - Comfy and weird fishing RPG

Atomic Runner Chelnov - Super difficult game and it's pretty unique.

Last Samurai - Western made Samurai game for SNES (originally Amiga IIRC), that has some really fun levels and boss fights. Kind of trippy with weird sound effects and baddies.

Quite yes. Interactivity is one of the defining traits of Nintendo's biggest early franchises. Mario and Zelda just let you do more THINGS to touch and feel and influence the world around you. Imagineering is a bunch of Atari 2600 devs who thought the 7800 was gonna beat the NES and didn't switch over to the NES until 1990. Their 2600-7800 roots is also the reason their games look like Atari 7800 games despite coming out the same year or later than SMB3.
At least VS. The World was consistently OK instead of falling off a cliff once you got past the rental zone.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9550190
>>9550194
"stacked" sprites technique is just the common way to make objects every game used. A sprite on NES is either 8x8 or 8x16. Note that you can't have both sizes at the same time, unlike on SNES; your entire game will either use 8x8 or 8x16, most games used 8x8 but Konami for instance was known for using 8x16 on most of their games.

Anyway, each of these invidual sprites can use any palette of 3 colours + transparency out of the 4 palette slots avalaible for sprites. Since Bart uses 4 colours that means they used 2 palette slots for the protagonist, leaving only 2 palette slots for the other objects (enemies etc), just like Mega Man does (when Inafune said MM is "two sprites" that is wrong, never believe interviews): pic related, an object made of nine 8x8 sprites, most of them use the same palette slot but the face uses a second one.
This was also a common technique.

After doing a quick google search, I learned that the KV-27FS100 has component at 480i only which makes it perfect for pairing it with the Analog I/O board and simply using a VGA to component breakout. Personally, my only concern is that since it's a flat panel (as opposed to curved), it will most likely have noticeable geometry warping which is very common but easy to get used to. >>9546440
>Have you ever tried those 30FPS and 60FPS patches for Starfox 1 and 2 which require an emulator running an SNES overclock to function properly on MiSTer?
I wouldn't mind testing it out if you can link me to your preferred resource.

>how well does it do with HDMI output?
That is actually the DE-10 Nano's native output. To mitigate display lag as much as possible, make sure the DE-10 Nano is rendering at your monitor's native resolution; highest it seems to do is 1440p@core's refresh rate, in order to prevent the display from processing the image through it's internal upscaler, and after that all you are left with is the display's own lag.

>Is it still viable to use HDMI or is there significant lag
At this point, if lag is still a concern, using SNAC will provide virtually no lag but there are USB options with arguably unnoticeable lag. The main advantage of using a digital display is that you don't have to tilt your display to play vertically oriented games (not just SHMUPs use this orientation).
>issues that make analog far more preferable
Regarding analog and CRTs, I recommend going through the playlist below that covers these topics in much better detail. The best summary I can make is that you get the game's intended input timing and appearance using a CRT as your display.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLn5sTGew1WGCMO7Bi-MD7VgFWAoeXbU93

>>9546568
>Wouldn't the RGB/Composite/VGA outputs the MiSTer has still be too high quality for these effects that depend on blur to work properly?
The MiSTer can output to composite natively now with MikeS' Y/C board and the unofficial Y/C cores. The active filtering Y/C board has the best you can get out of composite which does away with the rainbowing and dot crawl. The Y/C board also comes with S-Video output if you want a cleaner signal for text heavy games or arcade games that were meant to be displayed on RGB monitors.

>>9547503
I suspect the Retro Castle adapter works more like a transcoder (Antonio's and Jam's are like this) since it is reportedly compatible with main cores. From what I've read, it still has dot crawl, which is normal without active filtering. These are only worth getting if you are an S-Video user.

MikeS' adapters are merely VGA breakouts which require special Y/C cores in order to display the signal properly. His passive filter adapters are perfect for S-Video users and have minimal artifacts over composite. The active filter will completely eliminate rainbow and dot crawl over composite.

Here is a brief demonstration of that.
https://twitter.com/qda/status/1601258366239920128

>>9548384
It's limited in the number of games available but significantly better in terms of accuracy. In fact there's now a weird symbiotic relationship where the MiSTer cores use the MAME implementation as a base, figures out the bugs, and then that core ends up being used to fix bugs in MAME.
Same limitations apply though, there's an upper ceiling to how complex the cores can be. I don't even think Model 1 is possible, but CPS3 is being worked on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9545857
>how could you exactly read a disc more accurately when in the end it relies mostly on the quality of the disc itself
You have to rip multiple discs. That's why there's a heavy emphasis on verification. If you rip three independent copies of Mega Man X4 and they all match then you can be satisfied saying the rip is accurate. If two match and the third is different than you have to check. Is it a different revision or was the disc scratched? It's a veritable pain in the ass, especially since a lot of CD drives don't read all the data in the same way, which is why the Plexor drive is so special. In the end it's all 1s and 0s but the way the media is physically designed makes it hard to do all the forensics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9545826
CHD is a lossless container format (like FLAC is to WAV) that basically saves you chunks of space by removing the dummy padding data (a file that is filled with a bunch of zeros). This dummy padding data is used to help the optical laser access the data faster, which is useless in an emulation environment. If you compare Tony Hawk's Pro Skater on PS1, the raw bin/cue is about 600MB, but the CHD file is roughly 300MB. Some 300MB bin/cue games turn out to be a mere 10MB in CHD. It's the best format to use for archiving, and can be converted back to bin/cue or iso if that's what you wanna use or want to burn it to a real disc.

Redump is nice for some stuff like PS1 discs but god damn their autism is just too much sometimes.
They've decided that all Dreamcast discs must absolutely be dumped with a PC using a special drive and a whole load of fuckery and black magic rather than using a modded Dreamcast. Why? Because there's a few bytes of data on a few very specific discs that the Dreamcast drive can not read.

I've never tried it myself, but it seems like this control scheme would probably work just fine if you got used to it. I grew up on NES, so I'm used to attack being on a left face button, and jump being on a right face button. With MMX I added dashing to L, and with MMZ I added secondary weapon to R. With newer games I just added new buttons to what I was already used to from older games. Just because these controls work perfectly fine and feel natural to me after playing action platformers this way for decades, doesn't make it the only good control scheme. If you're a youngster whose first game was Halo, Minecraft, or Souls, it makes sense that you might gravitate towards controls that put your primary actions on shoulder buttons. Putting your primary actions on shoulder buttons is completely unnecessary in a game where you don't need to use the right analog stick to move your camera, but that doesn't mean that it's /wrong/ either. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

No. It’s the gp2x the successor to the gp32 the first handheld emulation machine ever made, shit for brains. Both of these consoles were huge in the home brew scene and sparked the handheld emulation scene we have today. I’m dead serious. Gamepark split up after making the gp32, which caused the gp2x to be made, but the teams were competing with each other which eventually led to the pyra and the gpd win to be the competitors. That was the beginning of the hand held computer and handheld emulation machine fad that we see now. It all stems from the massive home brew scene on the gp32 and gp2x. It doesn’t get you very far being a dumb faggot, but now you know.

For example, since Blast Hornet resides in a Weapon Factory the missle launcher enemies are down graded after you beat the level to signify you have delayed shipments. Volt Catfish provides some visual differences giving electricity to lights and I think activating some elevators. There also are some cool bits in level design like the secret path to the ride armor in Blast Hornet or the mass explosion in the Crush Crawfish stage. Not to mention using weaknesses on Vile etc changes up the last levels. The ride armors are definitely pretty useless, but much cooler at the time because fuck yeah robots. I honestly think anyone who trashes on X3 barely played it or is too dimwitted to see what goes on through out the game play
>>9548246

It's Capcom.
>Upgrades that exist to only get other upgrades
Hardly the case. The initial armor upgrades are just about more useful than the chips you can add on. It's just an extra incentive and reward.

What do you mean? You just charge it. Unless you are talking about the second upgrade for it which yeah is implemented pretty poorly.

Maybe, but it properly demonstrates the animation. It's probably a good choice game design anyway that you can't just instantly dash up into the air.
>Snail Climb
Like the elevators? Yeah they were slow but in the 90s as you know fighting on elevators was based. I think you can actually skip and wall jump up some to save time.

The Force Engine Linux port with working Audio and MIDI playback thanks to mlauss!
https://github.com/mlauss/TheForceEngine/tree/test-audio-select

Clone branch and compile then start Fluidsynth with
> fluidsynth -a alsa -m alsa_seq -g 1.0 -s /usr/share/sounds/sf3/default-GM.sf3
(or similar)

Then run the compiled binary and go to Settings > Sound > MIDI Output Device and specify the MIDI Output Device.

Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9540012
>>9540247
I think this map is okay but I have many nitpicks that I'll try to address roughly in order of appearance. I wish there were a few more bullets at the start since shooting the elevated skeletons at the start feels drawn out with the shotgun. I really dislike that some of the rock/sand piles around the start have impassible lines for no reason since it can block your dodging without any telegraph. This is especially annoying since not all of them are like this. Like the other post said already, many descended midtextures are visibly clipping through the floor with software rendering (you can fix this by varying the brightness value or flat between the surrounding sectors). The ambush before the rocket launcher is a blatant example of hitscanners without cover, the computer in the center isn't tall enough to protect you. I wish there were some consistency about which doors are intractable since inert/onesided doors look the same as normal ones. Using spectres as soon as you enter a dark room twice in the same map feels kind of lazy. Both archviles feel poorly used since the first one is trivial since he can never get behind you and the other is just a test of patience since it can never get down the lift. I didn't realize there was a lift at first since there's no indication it's intractable and it looks the same as the surrounding walls. I feel like the revenant/imp ambush by the computer switches would work a lot better if the wall above you were shorter so the enemies could shoot down at you when they get caught against the wall. I have no idea what the switch before the blue key lift is for since it seems like you can and should safely ignore it. The lost souls in the end room feel completely pointless since you can just kill them before you hit the switch, I'd honestly just remove them since the fight's hard enough anyway. You can also softlock yourself if you ride the perpetual lifts in that room up and jump over the wall. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541481
A lot of the interconnectedness in this level feels unmotivated since it'll often lead you places you have no reason to return to. The visuals in the map are unpolished, I don't know why you'd use a high quality texture pack like Otex if you aren't even going to align your textures (not just aligning your similar textures to each other but also aligning seams of the textures with the edges of geometry. Otex was designed from the ground up for this, I'm not sure why so many people don't bother). Using a combination of stock and Otex also tends to look incongruous, you can sometimes get away with it but it shouldn't really be necessary given the latter's comprehensiveness.
This probably comes off as a scathing review but I'd like to stress that none of these things ruin the map, and I liked many of the ideas present even if the execution was flawed. I especially liked the big imp ambush and the last room, minus the lost souls. If you're interested in contributing to community projects I'd say you're already more capable than a lot of participants.

>>9542926
The problem is that, A, this requires the attention of sufficiently educated and dedicated programmers who know Build, and then, B, for the ones who do to get over that Mapster32 really is an antiquated piece of shit which is holding the community back.

You know one of the big reasons Doom's mapping got such a powerful second wind in the 2000s? Because Doom Builder became a thing, and Doom Builder was a MONUMENTAL evolution in map making software for the game, all the programs proceeding it where clunky and awkward pieces of shit which sucked to use, with Doom Builder being incredibly easy to use and convenient, that program is one of the most important things in this community. Build modding and mapping communities clinging to Mapster32 is like if the Doom community had refused to move past DeepSEA, that shit would have murdered our momentum.

Build mapping is inherently more complex than mapping for Doom or any derivative of it, so the barrier of entry will remain higher, but the tools do not need to be this horrible relic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542820
I suggest trying to break out of the "room to door to room to door and repeat" layout cycle.
Also the texturing is very ugly. It looks like you're trying to fit in as many colors as possible, which ends up blurring the level's theme. A lot of these textures don't fit together. Moss-filled gray bricks with bright startans, solid grays, wood, bright tech blues, planks and bright silver... this all doesn't really fit together. It's best to stick to a few select textures that will be mainly used throughout the whole level or particular sections of it, if wanted, transitioning between themes smoothly.
The layout looks very basic and flat indeed, and I can tell there's not much reason behind those enemy placements: two Arachnotrons in a small, tight corridor. Arachnotrons fit best in large rooms, due to their big size and continuous attack that covers a lot of ground, much like Mancubi.
There's a lot of unintuitive cannon fodder fights, such as zombiemen with pinkies, or a block formation of Imps, and a few lone shotgunners that will provide absolutely no challenge or incentive interesting movement from the player. There's a single Baron that the player will either encounter after activating a lift down or that is defending the top of the staircase, again, in a tight corridor, with enough space that a single Baron is probably just gonna serve as a boring meatshield.
Last but not least... I'm betting you're using CC4-tex? Drop that shit. Ugly texture pack imo. Those recolors of vanilla textures (such as the ugly brown/orange space door) are so... unnecessary.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542820
Flatness and unflatness are both useful depending hugely on all the other aspects of the design and what your intentions actually are. There's no point in trying to judge a map based solely on a single image anyway unless you're only concerned with aesthetics. Even if you can infer something about the level design from looks it will always be liable to misunderstanding. If you want meaningful feedback on a map you should post something playable, and if you don't have anything playable yet then there's not much feedback to give.
>>9548947
I think the entire idea of this project is unrealistic. Aside from alienating participants with a premise that's weird and logistically difficult you're also potentially cutting the maps per person in half by design. "Unrattled", which was released less than a month ago only got 11 maps despite being comparatively normal, I don't think we have enough active mappers here to accomplish even an episode wad given the circumstances. I certainly don't want it to fail but it seems like an uphill battle.
Looking back at the participation rates for the previous /vr/ projects reveals that the best attended ones (with at least 32 maps) are the units/minutes/lindefs of /vr/ series. This indicates to me that this board is mostly interested in making, vaguely, "simple maps for doom2". Any deviation from that formula is probably going to dissuade participation. Sometimes that could be desirable if it makes for a higher quality overall but I think you've reached a tipping point where the idea simply can't make anything.

>don't forget the whole "saturn was popular in japan" meme, when the system stopped getting any real games in japan after 1998
That's because they dropped support for it immediately after the Dreamcast came out, much to the annoyance of a lot of developers and consumers. It's part of why the Dreamcast didn't really take off in Japan and why it didn't really get the same level of third party support that the Saturn got in Japan.

The truth of the matter is that the Saturn actually was doing well in Japan. The system had outsold the N64 in both hardware and software. While the N64 had more first party titles breaking 1 million, it's sales fell off a cliff once you got outside of that. While on the Saturn third party titles were actually selling fairly well in Japan. It was enough that it was turning heads of companies like Konami to start testing the waters with ports of big name PS1 games like Suikoden, Vandal Hearts, and Symphony of the Night, with Metal Gear Solid apparently being looked into. But then Sega abruptly pulled the plug on it once the Dreamcast came out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542957
>They were losing billions of yen on making the console
No they weren't. The losses on hardware pretty much stopped by around 1996 when the Model 2 system came out. At launch they were losing about $100 per system, which is the same loss Sony was taking on the PS1. But as RAM prices fell and the hardware was more consolidated it got a lot cheaper to produce. The massive loss people post graphs showing is from the fact that Sega of Japan wrote off a bunch of unsold Genesis inventory that was sitting at Sega of America which lowered the perceived value of the US Branch as that inventory was being marked on financials as assets.
>the only title that sold good was Virtua Fighter and maybe Sakura Taisen.
You think that having 5 games selling over 1 Million means N64 sold more software? You're not looking at the big picture. When you look at the actual sales data you see that Saturn had a lot more games selling well and charting in the weekly sales charts. This site documents all the Famitsu sales charts of the era. And it shows that Saturn had a lot more games charting over it's run than the N64 did.
https://sites.google.com/site/gamedatalibrary/game-search

And from official shipped numbers from Nintendo, and Sega's FY98 report we know that N64 sold about 39 Million games in Japan, and Saturn sold close to around 54 Million games in Japan. It outsold the N64 in both hardware and software.

>Saturn had too poor of a software attach rate to do well.
From Sega's FY98 report they had sold 8.8 Million Saturn's worldwide, and 80 Million Saturn games worldwide. That would put the worldwide attach rate at ~9:1. The Japanese attach rate was probably higher than that as that average is being pulled down by the systems poor western performance. N64's attach rate by comparison was about 6-7:1.

>It outsold the N64 for one quarter in a 4 year period
It outsold the N64 while it was actively being supported.

>Are you mentally retarded?
Are you? Do you not understand the key factor here? Sega of America was producing Genesis games and Systems like it was still 1992 well into 1996. And on top of it they were including that unsold inventory that was piling up in warehouses as assets in their financials. When Shoichiro Irimajiri took over as CEO of Sega of America after Kalinske he quickly realized how mismananged the US branch was and how much the financials were being misrepresented. One of the first things he did was fix all that. That resulted in things that were being included as assets in Sega of America's financials to suddenly no longer be there as they were written off as what they actually were, losses. This is what caused the large loss that was reported in the FY98 report. It's all there in the first 2 pages:
https://segaretro.org/images/f/fe/AnnualReport1998_English.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9546382
the 2d rule only works for two type of games:
- they use a ton of animation frames, Saturn is better because more RAM
- they heavily use 2d background effects, which Saturn has a specific chip for (also saving some RAM)

Anything else, and the Saturn does not have an advantage in 2D. If a game abuses sprite effects and sprite transparency, the Saturn even has a disadvantage, because it can't mix those effects with the backgrounds.

So the Saturn does archaic stuff like CPS2 and MVS ports better due to memory, Taito F3 ports better due to hardware scroll effects. But more advanced games like Castlevania or even Disney's Hercules or Skullmonkeys would be significantly worse on Saturn.

posts.com: FFVIII should have opened with the beach invasion like the demo implied it would. Every FF game starts in medias res, throwing you into an event you have no context for that's relatively high stakes and only afterwards does it slow down and start explaining the basics of the world and story. Mednafen is much more accurate but it's accurate to a fault, as there's certain games that use hacky ways to interact with the hardware that Mednafen can do without the dev rewriting everything which they don't want to do.
Duckstation doesn't care about being completely accurate so those hacky games run fine, which equals to some anons that it's more compatible.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9547639
So Mednafen is inaccurate in a different way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9547647
Not at all. ZSNES is much more comparable to ePSXe.
Duckstation uses some Mednafen code to create a more hardware-powered enhancement focused PS1 emulator that runs as nice as Mednafen does but with less of a hang-up on pure accuracy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9547653
Inaccurate in the way that it as it is can't support certain outlier games that use the PS1 hardware in weird ways. It's not seen as something the dev really wants to do anything with because said games are a either some weird licensed games or older Simple Series titles. Plus the dev is focusing on the Saturn part of Medanfen more often then not these days. They've barely touched the PS1 module in the past year or so.

Emurayden is basically a hacked up version of Connectix VGS (virtual game station), an old ass emulator before that epsxe thing got popular.

I kind of accepted that ALTTP is the only real masterpiece among 2D Zeldas. A real adventure with great pacing and sense of openness. The forest feels mystical to this day and scaling the mountains truly menacing. The ones that came before aren't really Zelda and more Nintendo spitballing and the ones that came after are too much on the goofy side with way too many puzzles, obstacles, references and fun but rather unpolished gameplay ideas like jumping. Link's Awakening might be a close second. Never played ALBW, and I'm sure it's good, but it does ruin some of the visuals and rehashes quite a bit without maintaining the same level of sophistication

Anon it's called investment. It's not like Ion Storm was spending Romero's money, it was spending Eidos' money. Normally video game publishers are unwilling to back startups nowadays because Ion Storm isn't even unusual in how retarded and ass backwards things ended up.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9544364

Honestly I'm more impressed by someone being a video game programmer back in the day, even if they were shit at it, because it was a new field and not at all prestigious or lucrative.
People were coding stuff in their spare time at home and mostly dealing with how to implement ideas they randomly had or trying to reverse-engineer games they liked. Nothing was done for fame or virtue signaling.

I remember my dad used to buy these ZX81/Spectrum magazines that had entire pages of code in them. You would literally transcribe the code from the magazine and you got a playable game out of it.
Point being that there was a love and pursuit of discovery there and the entire gaming field was uncharted waters. Real pioneers.

>>9532823
There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.

>>9535508
I actually saw it from a totally different perspective, to me it was like "hmmmm never seen this kinda stuff before.."
lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.
back then most of us just didn't even feel like we could be subjected to kids games on the Genesis, Snes for sure cuz Nintendo. but Genesis just felt differently.
you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

Even now when I go through my rom collection and find stuff like Richard Scarry's Busytown it feels.. off somehow. as in "this shouldn't be on the Genesis"
That's just how it was marketed, even Lion King and Aladdin didn't feel like they were for kids, they were for all ages.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

>9544839 here, I was around 14 when it came out and I think it just hit at a really good time. It was obtuse, bit I liked games like that. It helped that others at school were playing it so we'd talk about stuff at lunch which is how I learned how to use the red crystal. I can see how it would be more frustrating without that , but many games were similar back then.

What I really liked was it was a platform game, but in a huge open world complete with day night cycle where I could just explore and figure out what to do. To me that's one of my favorite things in games and why I also love Ecco so much. The areas weren't as challenging or interesting in terms of platforming, it's true but I still think it's pretty fun and a fine trade off for the other aspects.

Really it's the precursor to what SotN would be which is another game I love but there I wish it had taken a few more notes from SQ and been at least somewhat more of a challenge.

>>9533387
It does but it's a huge pain. The only way I can get DualShock rumble to work the way it does on console is to add Duckstation to Steam so it sees it as an Xinput controller, then change the vibration bias to like 138 in the controller options to actually get it to vibrate each motor correctly. Otherwise Playstation controllers overall don't rumble right when wrapped as Xinput (even the DS4 it turns out, although Duckstation supports that natively) and support for vibration as a Dinput controller is non-existent. I think you can accomplish this in PCSX2 as well (and I think that has some DS3 mode which might work for that controller, or is that RPCS3?) by changing the vibration percentages above 100% but I don't actually use PCSX2 so I'm not going to fiddle with it.

There's an Xbox One converter and I have no idea if it handles it any better and accounts for the different vibration standards or just does the same shit as the software input wrappers.

>>9546769
And actually you know my end conclusion from this odyssey is that the vibration on all this shit is not really as inherently different as I thought but every fucking controller has different strength values (I mean I have 2 DS2s that vibrate noticeably different even, whether that's just because one is worn out) and every fucking piece of software on PC has different output values and in particular one of my test cases (Armored Core Project Phantasma in Duckstation because in Retroarch and Mednafen it has no rumble for some reason) those values are on the edge of where the light landing effect is strong enough to actually do anything on one controller and not the others. If I try an Xbox series controller and then a PS1 DualShock in GT2 in Retroarch or in MHW they're about as similar as two physically different controllers produced over two decades apart can be and not so far off of real hardware as Duckstation's default settings, if I crank the rumble strength up in DS4Windows on my DS4 it not only feels pretty similar there's actually something in MHW that it picks up the Xbox controller doesn't.

Also what confuses things even more is that even just how the controller is getting power over USB can affect how strong the rumble is. Basically as far as matching the developer's intent unless you're dealing with a brand new launch console with its packed in controller shit is wack man, and trying to subjectively match a real console in an emulator is the only kind of "right" anyone can hope for on PC, which doesn't do any good for anyone that doesn't have a real console to compare to.

Now putting aside the dozens up dozens of laps of Midfield Raceway in GT2 and Laguna Seca in Tourist Trophy I've done trying to understand this shit I should stop pissing around and play some fucking video games.

>>9547005
>In 1994, video game developers Wolf Team signed a deal with publisher Namco to release the game that would be Tales of Phantasia, which was later released in 1995 in Japan for the Super Famicom.[22] However, the development cycle for this game was plagued with creative disputes between the developers and publisher, leading to much of the development team leaving to form a new company, which would become tri-Ace, which explains some of the common themes between the games, such as the similar battle systems.[1]

>After Tales of Phantasia was completed, some of the game's designers felt that the core skill and item systems were too "generic", and for their next game they would make a much deeper gameplay experience.[23] To deepen the story, the "private action" system was created to reveal more of the characters history, personality and relationships, but the score the game generated from various choices was hidden from players since there was no "right" or "wrong" story path.[23] In order to tell a "bigger" story, space was chosen as the setting.[23]

>>9545221
>The retro Basara games do not have good gameplay.
1 arguably still has the best for some characters because it has two dedicated attack strings, contrary to what you're saying, with what feels like infinite combo potential and flow, unlike musou combos, which are the prime example of context sensitivity, all lead to a dead end and one flashy finisher you spam because it's the strongest. 2 makes up with characters that have some of the best character-action gameplay, animations gimmicks, etc. you can find scattered among them, be it Konjuro with an aura ability that doubles his moves and gives him a pissed-off-yakuza fighting style, Tadakatsu who literally turns the game into Gundam, Nohime who literally turns the game into a gallery shooter and has Dante moves (Saika in later games), Yoshihiro who is very slow but can even one-shot bosses with one well-timed attack, all the aerial combos and parries with Fuma, the pirate who can surf non-stop on top of fast combos, Mitsuhide who can turn damage received into powerful attacks, Ranmaru who turns the game into a Dragon's Dogma bow class and is small enough to not get hit by huge enemies, characters like Nagamasa or of course Keiji, both of which you can play if you like the muso combos, with the latter actually allowing you to do infinite combos that take more skill and are more fun to pull off than everything in a musou game (not to mention doing soulful things like resting to fill your Basara Bar while you can control his pet monkey to protect you). Sengoku Basara is all about character identity. It's musous that sometimes throw a hundred generic gooks at you that literally all play the same because you can just give them any weapon/fighting style. If you play Basara games smart, alternate between characters a lot (and ideally just download a savegame because unlocking moves sucks), even the retro Basaras are better

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My quest to play as many RPGs as I can on NES/Famicom continues. While I prioritize classic turned based RPGs, once in a while I play hybrid games as long as they're turned based and the occasional A-RPG. Here is the latest I played and a few words

>Gegege no Kitarou 2 - Youkai Gundan no Chousen (Spooky Kitaro 2 - Kitaro Versus Yokai Army)

For 1987 excellent combat: great graphics (backgrounds + characters on the same screen in a very smart way), very dynamic with movement and projectiles when attacking.
The game is properly balanced for the first half (a bit challenging) but max level is reached half way through the game, from that point onwards there is no point in fighting random encounters anymore. Also, a couple of cryptic stuff to progress through the game despite the in game clues.
posts.filename: Gegege no Kitarou 2 - Youkai Gundan no Chousen (Spooky Kitaro 2 - Kitaro Versus Yokai Army)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Cleopatra no Mahou (The Cursed Treasure of Cleopatra)

A somewhat short adventure/RPG by Square, one of the last games they made before Nasir joined them and they made Final Fantasy. Very simple both in terms of adventure and RPG elements although there had to be one clue-less item puzzle required to progress.
Still managed to grab my attention, nice graphics. A bit grindy.
posts.filename: Cleopatra no Mahou (The Cursed Treasure of Cleopatra)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Kawa no Nushi Tsuri (Legend of the River King)

Fishing/RPG hybrid. The game is all about grind. You grind the fish?ing segment for money, and you grind the turned based RPG battles with random encounter to level up as all the wild life in the entire world is out to kill you, from rats to bears. Then you can reach the next section and repeat while upgrading your fishing equipments on the way and solving the occasional simple item puzzle. Very repetitive but I understand this double grind to be someone's idea of relaxing, and it spawned an entire series.
I found two main flaws: one, the best way to make money seems to be right at the start of the game, at least once you get a middle class rod, so I found it best to backtrack there every time I needed money. Two, the only way to regain two of the five bait types (including the most important one required to beat the game) seems to be to use a password.
posts.filename: Kawa No Nushi Tsuri (Legend of the River King)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Dai 2 Ji Super Robot Taisen (Super Robot Wars 2)

Tactics game with exp/lvl-up and a shop system. Basically Fire Emblem with mecha robots from manga and anime. I know nothing about any of the source material. Each unit is unique and behaves differently, plus most of them have several variants, either transformations you can switch to at any time to get the best of any situation or upgrades along the game. This is where the game shines as each unit/character is truly unique.
Unlike FE, the shop system is basically inexistant/irrelevant which is somewhat a relief if you've played FE1 and like me had to spend hours micro managing items, however money is also used to repair defeated units at the end of a mission and this is where the player needs to be careful. There are 26 missions, about the same as FE1. Difficulty seemed really easy, definitely easier than the two Famicom Fire Emblem.

>>9543201
Outside of the usual DQ/FF, which are undeniably some of the bests jRPGs on the system (my personal favourite being DQ2 and FF2, which should give you an idea of my taste), the best I've played so far are Earthbound Beginnings, Digital Devil Story Megami Tensei II and Metal Max.
Every once in a while in my daily file I find myself randomly thinking about Metal Max 1 and Metal Max 2 on SFC and how good those games made me feel.

Outside of that the most underrated game one I've played so far is probably Namco's Dream Master, which is a hybrid adventure/RPG game that plays a lot like Sweet Home in many ways. Then you have the DQ clones I really liked like Ninjara Hoi!, SD Keiji - Blader and Jubei Quest, but they're not something I'd recommend to someone before many others.

The worst is Bloody Warriors Shan Go, the game is basically a tech demo that one would pitch to a publisher in order to try and make a real game. Then I really disliked LaSalle Ishii no Child's Quest and Destiny of an Emperor, that last one probably being the only hot take I have considering how famous the game seems to be in the US (imo only because it's one of the few that got officially released)

Also I really liked Dragon Ball 2 as well, which is an adventure/RPG/card hybrid game. For a supposed licenced shovelware game that only lasts a few hours I thought it was really good and I'm not even such a big fan of the franchise. Shame DB3 hasn't been translated. In comparison I played all the DBZ games as well (all 4 of them though the last one doesn't count as RPG) and I thought they were only okay despite the awesome presentation

posts.com:
>>9544074
I played them all except Metal Saga on DS and Xeno. 1 and 2 remain my favourites, and the more time passes and the more I think 2 was stellar.

Returns was great, I especially liked the new content and being able to use it to sequence break.

Saga on PS2 has a great world and interesting changes to the gameplay, however balance is whack and the game is too easy. Due to how the exp/lvl system works it is way too easy to gain a couple of levels and find yourself untouchable just because you walked a few steps into the other direction. Also, battle speed (especially due to animation) is extremely slow, I shit you not some enemies attack like those balloon soldiers take up to 30 seconds (and of course you get several enemies per turn)

Then there are 3, 2:R and 4 which all belong in the same style of visuals and gameplay. Their strength come from the tons of content and replay value, and you will always find a way to break the game in a ridiculous fashion if you look.
I thought something was lost in those 3 games though, in the previous ones there was a balance between despair in a post apocalyptic world and lightheartedness. In 2R, 3 and 4 I do not know where the despair has gone to, replaced by whacky stuff.

I do not speak Japanese so for 2 on SNES and 4 I used Retroarch AI translate tool which worked okay for the most part (better for 4 than 2) if only that it requires patience. I think 4 is being translated though. I couldn't do that for Saga on DS because that game is touchscreen only and for some reasons the mouse for emulating touchscreen is completely offset for me in retroarch

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Decided to go for Just Breed, a tactic/RPG by Enix from 1992. Goddamn!

Unlike Fire Emblem or >>9542996 the game leans more towards the RPG elements. You can explore towns, talk to people, have shops, etc However the combat is tactical grid based. Unlike FE/Famicom Wars, an attacked unit will not retaliate on the turn it is attacked. Gameplay is based around generals, the player has up to 4 teams (so far) each with 1 general and 5 units usually composed of fighters, archers, and mages (offensive or defensive). Units of a general can not leave the current screen the general is on, so it is him that gives the overall movement of the team.

Game's pretty neat so far, nice graphics and musics, although a bit easy so far. You can replay battles to grind for exp/gold and the game seems to expect you to do that at least if you want to buy an acceptable amount of gear in shops.
What's impressive about it is the amount of characters the game can have on the screen at once. What it actually does is use background graphics for the characters, unless it is currently the unit in play in which case it will turn into a sprite for the time being. Pretty smart, but even then it is impressive.
>>9547529
I assume the sequels improve upon the first game. Sometimes first games are some of the bests in the series, but in the case of Legend of the River King I feel like there was a lot of room for improvement.

Welp, I think I'm coming up on the finale of the game in my hard mode playthrough of GoW1. I'd be lying if I said this game wasn't completely fucked on hard, and I probably would've had more fun if I had just restarted on normal (getting your ass kicked only lets you go down to easy). It's one thing for the combat to be as hard as it is, with enemies randomly armoring through your attacks, doing 1 frame wakeup attacks, and easily killing you in the blink of an eye if you get ganged up on, but combine that with some truly awful platforming and you've got a pretty annoying experience. It's still entertaining enough, but I'd be lying if I said I didn't turn fast forward mode on a few times during the padding stuff, like when you have to slowly drag a rock a mile across the screen.
Still, it's not been an overall bad experience. I'd give it like a C+ or maybe even a B-, you could do a lot worse for a hack n slash on the PS2. Hoping GoW2 is better (will play on normal in that one).

It just overwrites a bunch of values in memory. Basically most things like player health etc. are stored as variables in RAM. The gameshark overwrites the values to "fool" the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538312
Find the part of the memory that stores the timer value. Set it to biggest allowed integer.

nice

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9539240
Or:
>change the decrement amount on the timer to 0
>change the timer check to always return as true (or false, depending on which one triggers the time-over)
>NOP the jump operation to the timer function

Since you're from a different time period it may seem a bit foreign to you. Most people back then didn't sit down and play video games all day. They'd put in a game and do a 20~120 minute session there do something else like play with their other toys, hobbies, or go outside. Eventually video games on a wider scale became something the developers wanted the player to play hours on end every day. Hence why you have these 10+ hour games that weren't RPGs.

Pretty much any JRPG, but especially Final Fantasy games. They literally aren't good games. They're not fun to play.

>>9524813
I played a part of KH1 as a kid and played through the whole game a couple weeks ago. I had a good enough time, though I found it pretty easy once you got Second Chance. Then I played KH2 which I had never played. I dropped 2. I think a little bit of the jank worked for the first game, prevented you from being too much of a god and gave you reason to use your other abilities. I've seen people insist 2 isn't just mash X to win and your magic is good, but it felt like they streamlined melee attacks but not magic so you either mash X and do a ton of damage or you entirely break your flow to cast a couple spells that do next to nothing. It didn't help that it felt like 2 was dripfeeding you spells, too. I ended up dropping 2 because the combat just wasn't very interesting to me and the amount of cutscenes was just frustrating with how often it took control away from you. And that Roxas intro was so dull.

Overall, I think KH1 was the better game, even though it had its annoyances; I found that I probably didn't finish the game as a retarded child because I kept thinking "where the fuck do I go" and it'd be things like climbable vines that didn't stand out well enough against a tree and things like that.

Yeah, when they’re done well.

Inserting cartoon characters into an already well-established and popular aesthetic (in this case basketball/hip hop) works because it doesn’t break the layer of irony that comes with it. In the case of those Looney Tunes, it’s “cool” because it’s kind of funny.

Whereas with this shit >>9525010, it’s Mickey Mouse trying WAY too hard to look cute in an edgy, almost emo sort of way. >what the fuck did he mean by this?

We can’t feasibly see this as funny, because it’s evident that Mickey is 100% serious about looking like he belongs in a fucking boyband. There is no layer of irony to it, and that is what makes it awkward and uncool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Also I do agree with posts above, end game Sora in KH1 feels very balanced compared to end game Sora in KH2

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

Really wished the gameplay would have remained good because Square had something great going on before they killed the franchise with BBS (I also like this entry though but modern KH is nothing like what KH1 and KH2 used to be)

>>9524382
I was 10 when this came out. This shit was mindblowing to a kid. I grew up with Disney cartoons and FF7 was one of the first games I had on PS1. The commercial with simple and clean would play all the time. Yeah this shit was dope, what a time to be alive.
Thankfully I wasn’t super autistic, but the wave of autism this caused at some kids in school was immense (I am thinking about one annoying retard in particular).
Sequel was good too but wasn’t nearly as magical, mostly liked it for Tron world.

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9547307
If you look closely you will see that the Baolian X-G is paired with a knock-off SNES d-pad that has worse tolerances and build quality. That's what the Baolian X-G is. It's a clone of a JLF with louder, worse switches, worse quality control, and worse tolerances for each part's fitting.
However, it's still an alright lever and could probably be tweaked to be just as good as a JLF.

Best is subjective and depends on what you're going for. A JLW is an 80s lever that was found in Irem Madonna cabinets. Madonna cabs were popular after-market cabinets not sold by the bigger companies like Sega, Taito, or Namco. And the games that got put in them were probably lower-budget and lesser known titles.

So if you want to play certain 80s games just as they were a JLW could be a great pick. But is it "the best"? Well, I probably wouldn't pick it as a first choice to play fighting games with. Although I've heard it actually works pretty well for later era games.
Would you play Street fighter II with a Famicom d-pad?

Shaders are only half of the equation. The best ones already emulate scanlines and phosphor masks very well when used at very high resolutions. However, the display matters a lot as well, and it's where the bottleneck truly lies. You need at least 4K resolution, HDR with very high brightness and strobing to properly replicate things like scanline bloom and smooth motion while having a nice vibrant picture. In lieu of that, some shaders try to fake the bloom and glow of a CRT screen, but these aren't all that convincing.

>>9548675
It actually depends on how good the implementations are.
G-Sync is usually better and has better granularity than Freesync for example but some Freesync implementations are better than some G-Sync implementations out there.

But in general Variable Refresh technologies beat the snot out of old-fashioned VSync.
At higher refresh rates even old consoles benefit because old consoles still had 16-17ms scanout lag due to 60hz-ish scanout but for example on a 360hz G-Sync/Freesync display you get 360hz scanout at all times which means you get far less scanout latency.

Compare for example SNES
16ms lag from game framerate(60fps) + 16ms framebuffer + 16ms lag from 60hz scanout = 48ms lag on original NES with 60hz CRT
vs
16ms lag from game framerate(60fps) + 16ms 60fps framebuffer + 360hz scanout(3ms) = 35ms(+ some varying degrees of lag if using emulation depending on frame delay settings etc.)
You get the point

>What I'm saying is that there are no big difference between a phone with a good 1080p and 4k screen.
And I'm saying that there objectively is, especially if your eyes are closer to the screen etc.
240p isn't all that different from 480p or 160p or whatever.

But the point is that you need a fuckton of resolution before you resolve the problem.
One of the biggest draw of higher resolutions is to not have to use anti-aliasing anymore. Even on a 4K monitor you still see aliasing problems in modern 4K games, that is if you mod them on PC to disable the Temporal Anti-Aliasing all of them use nowadays. 4K on 27 inch screen is aroud 160ish PPI and it's still nowhere near enough without AA applied. Even on a 300PPI screen phone if you play a modern game without AA it's still not enough.

To give you a perspective
To reach 12000ish PPI on say a 30 inch screen you would need a resolution of 320000x180000 which translates to a dot pitch of 0.0021mm which means each pixel is about 2.1 micrometers small.
So yeah it's a long way off but there is a solution to get rid of these screen-door, scanline artifacts and all this bullshit long-term.

Of course display researchers will never stop researching and improving displays and I think the limitation for color displays is about 700 nameters since below that you can't display Red primary but yeah.

We'll get there evetually altough 64K is only good enough for 16:9 6 inch screen as I pointed out for a screen size like 30 inch 16:9 screen 320K is needed to get the same PPI.

32K is already somewhat relevant enough to have its own wiki page
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/32K_resolution

There's this interesting new technology from a company called Porotech called "DynamicPixelTuning".
What this allows is for a single emitting LED to display the full color wavelength. This means you can get rid of the conventional RGB subpixels and this way according to them you can quadruple the resolution(4K screen turns into a 16K screen) and of course you get significantly better color purity with Whites being extremely pure due to not being an RGB mix and Violets, Cyans etc. looking purer.

One final thing I have to note is that running modern video games with cutting edge graphics at a native 320K probably won't be feasible in our lifetimes but running them a a more conventional 1080p/4K resolution and then near neighbour upscale them to 320K seems more feasible.
By that token I doubt we'll ever even see 4K TV broadcasts become mainstream in my lifetime but upscaling 1080i or 4K to absurd resoluton will look just as good as their native counterparts with the only thing remaining being the quality of the video bitrate which with better compression algorithms over time is getting better.

That's really not how any of this works.
To emulate phosphor decay you need 1000hz or more but 360hz can also do a good job.

Phosphor decay doesn't really make motion smoother, the opposite, you trade off some motion smoothness in the fall times for less flicker.

You can't accurately emulate a CRT with OLED however if you want it as authentic as possible.
OLED isn't as fast a CRT.
CRT's pixel rise times are on the nanoseconds(with the fall times aka the phosphor decay being much slower on the half millisecond to a few milliseconds).
MicroLED can do it no problem though.

>>9544506
The controllable camera was a nice addition and since you could toggle between it and the "cinematic" one at any time there was no real downside. But I find it weird how many people have this completely erroneous impression that the vanilla MGS3 camera was some kind of major problem. It wasn't.

First of all, you have first-person view, binoculars and scoped weapons. You can see as far as you want in any direction at any time so if you're running into enemies who caught you off-guard it's because you're impatient and were just plowing straight ahead indiscriminately.

And secondly, the camera isn't a static overhead one like so many people incorrectly describe it, the zoom and angle chance according to the terrain and enemy location so you're almost always getting a pretty good view of whatever you need to be looking at. The fixed camera is actually much better to use in certain segments, like some of the parts where you're climbing the mountainside and it zooms way out to give you a full field of view that you can't get from a camera centered on snake. And even though the camera is "fixed" you can still use the right analog stick to move the frame around. The fixed camera in MGS3 is about as good as a fixed camera can be. I understand why people still wanted some more control but it wasn't really ever a problem

>>9547015
>most of the time it's really bad and will cause you to get seen from offscreen

Again, it will if if you're just running around out in the open like it's not a stealth game but this myth about enemies seeing you before you even have a chance is bullshit. If you're careful, maintain cover and scope out the area before deciding how to proceed there are zero situations where the game funnels you into some kind of ambush that you couldn't see coming.

Now, that doesn't mean you won't misjudge when soldiers will turn their backs or forget about some random guy who sees you from a distance but that doesn't change with the subsistence camera. If anything, it has way more "blind spots," especially in places like the stairs in the warehouse. A lot of the rooms were clearly designed knowing the cmaera would pull back and show a panoramic view and it just doesn't work over the shoulder. Like I said, it's a nice option to have and adds to the game but it's not some drastic improvement that fixes something horribly broken in the original. The game was fine without it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The number you're looking for is the msrp (manufacturer's suggested retail price). That's basically the "official" price something was at launch, before the store marks it up/down. Since video games tend to have a relatively static price, companies generally didn't bother to advertise the msrp unless the game was particularly cheap. You can usually guess what it was by looking at store prices of the time, since it'll usually be the most common price point it was being sold at.

>>9533828
The switch started in Sonic Adventure 1 (Sonic and co start calling him Eggman) and Sonic Adventure 2 (Robotnik starts calling himself Eggman)
By SA1, Sega started going with a unified canon rather than having Japan and the west use different canons. Thus, the Robotnik name was canonized via Maria and Gerald Robotnik in SA2, but the doctor himself was consistently named Dr. Eggman (with the in-universe justification of it either being a nickname he claimed from Sonic or an alias).

>>9535273
Also, another reason this comparison fails is because Vader is a straightforward intimidating villain.
Dr. Robotnik, outside of SatAM and some western marketing, always has a silly undercurrent. He models mechas and a space station after himself. One game has Sonic defeat him by running very fast on a treadmill. He once blew up his own ship. An animation had him ruin Sonic's reputation in response to Sonic being named Man of the Year. The first game ends with him either juggling the emeralds Sonic missed or throwing a tantrum. Even Sonic Adventure, which played him more seriously on the surface, reveals that his personal battleship has amenities like a swimming pool and a toy room.
Eggman can be threatening, as the Sonic CD futures show, and I do feel that later games go too far with making him goofy, but his menace is usually juxtopositioned with his silliness. The comparison fails because Vader is a dead serious villain outside of media that parodies Star Wars.

>>9535403
It depends. The games just vaguely kinda suggested that Eggman wanted to rule the world. Sonic CD and the Sonic Technical Files suggest that it's because Eggman felt that machines were beautiful and could be controlled, with nature being a resource at best. CD goes further to imply that Eggman could even potentially be negligent to his own machines, as his badniks are rundown in the bad future.
>The evil doctor (also known as Eggman) has been a bad egg from the very beginning. Nobody knows quite where he came from, but he is definitely behind any problem that comes up. Dr. Robotnik loves machines. He loves them so much that his idea of a perfect world would be to have it full of nothing but machines. He thinks they are beautiful and he likes that he can control them. A genuine genius megalomaniac, he spends all of his time trying to replace the natural world with his beautiful machines. He is not very concerned about saving the planet (being a notorious polluter), and he particularly likes the idea of exploiting the oceans for their riches (This really gets to Sonic, because Sonic loves the oceans and can't stand the idea of Robotnik messing with them). In order to have ultimate control in his quest, Robotnik must find and control all of the Chaos Emeralds, and most importantly.....Sonic.
Around Sonic LabyrinthSonic Adventure, they gave a more solid goal of establishing an empire with the capital of Eggmanland/Robotnikland and the "mechanizing nature" aspect took more of a backseat.

Nope, I was born in the early 90s, and was playing Sonic 3 & Knuckles Collection for the PC in 1997. Also, most parents had a PC for work purposes, and would let their kids play around on it too.

>>9538086
So many Mario localization changes are utterly nonsensical ("Lakitu" doesn't mean a fucking thing), with Koopa --> Bowser being the worst of them. Before Super Mario Bros., the name Bowser was exclusively contextualized as a generic name for a pet dog in America. The whole arrangement is like if Hitler were renamed Fido, the SS were called Hitler Footlers, and good/neutral German characters in RPG spinoffs were called things like Hitla, Hits, and Hitomi. In games with more atypical localizations, like Super Mario RPG, they already blurred the lines between regions; a simple green Koopa shell is called a Noknok (Nokonoko) Shell, as it is in the original Japanese. I'm sure you're all familiar with SMB3 retaining Kuribo's Shoe and Jugem's Cloud. The changes were ultimately unnecessary and simply a product of their time.

"Goomba" is also worth mentioning as a particularly stupid localization. The original term applies more to Mario and Luigi than it does to the mushroom enemies. If Super Mario Bros. debuted today, there's no way they'd have changed the names like this. The older I get, the more it bothers me.

>>9527987
AoW seems to be written in Delphi, judging from the .dpl files (they're just dlls btw).
The UI uses the Visual Component Library that is based on Win32 API but adds a lot of custom controls. Looks like it was one of the easiest way to build good looking GUIs in Windows at the time.

As for VNs from that time, maybe they used the Windows API with custom engines in C or C++ or even languages like Hot Soup Processor.
Then engines like KiriKiri and Nscripter got popular.

>>9548076
As a kid the idea of owning an arcade cab sounded awesome. But let me tell you, the fastest way to get over that itch is to help a friend move one. In a commercial setting they don't seem THAT big but when you put them in a residential space with standard ceiling heights and door widths they suddenly become gigantic pieces of furniture that have a weird footprint which, if you don't have a dedicated game room, will interfere with how you set up the rest of your furniture. Plus you'll find that as neat as they are to look at, you don't really want to use them. In a social setting its all good but stand at one (or even sit) for a casual gaming session and you notice they're not built for comfort. It becomes a showpiece and conversation starter when you have guests but after a while its just an imposition. If you just want to play arcade games better to get a supergun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9548076
I have bought arcade machines. Lots of them.
Would I do it again?
No.
And I'll tell you why in exactly one word: ergonomics.

Cabs are just not that comfortable to play nor are they easy to work with. They are meant for a commercial setting. Your needs as a home player are different and a cabinet is not a good solution for that.

The biggest practical advantage of a cabinet is the stability. However that can be recreated building a podium or small heavyweight table.
Or in even more practical real-world scenarios just putting your arcade stick onto something stable. Or realizing that playing in your lap isn't actually that bad at all. How else would world champion fighting game players manage?

The CRT and controls are important. The actual cabinet not so much.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9548883
>every PC game ever prior to Steam era either has a CD key or no DRM
Are you a fucking retard, anon?
LaserLock, StarForce, the fuckton of SecuROM variants, TAGES and numerous other protections were all implemented on older disc-based games
Most of those relied on read errors decoded in various ways that couldn't be simply copied over to another disc. StarForce is especially infamous since it installs a custom driver for your disc drive that fucking sucks.
Most of these protections no longer work since they usually relied on low-level access to the disc drive which modern Windows no longer allows due to security concerns. Unfortunately some games only ever had DRM bypasses on them rather than full removal so those can't be played even with no-cd patches.
For example it took over a decade before some russian autist managed to removed StarForce from Trackmania Sunrise. The older scene crack from back in the day simply couldn't be used on modern Windows because it relied on StarForce protection still being installed and working, it just bypassed some checks for it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think that out of all super heroes, Spider-Man is the one that's got the better treatment from video games, of course that perception changed over time due to Batman getting his well received Arkham series in the last decade, but before that it was pretty much unanimous that Spider-Man had the best video game career out of all super heroes. I remember playing Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six as a kid, it was my first ever experience with a video game based on my favorite super hero, and it was quite good, nothing superb, but it doesn't deserve the poor reception it usually gets, it plays fine enough and has some good level design.

What I really remember from my childhood however, is the PS1 duology of Spider-Man and Spider-Man 2: Enter Electro. I couldn't believe how accurate these were, you really felt like you were Spider-Man, and the jump to 3D helped with that quite a lot. I recall growing up and hoping that there'd be a 3rd installment, but there wasn't, the Sam Raimi films came out and, while I loved those, and both Spider-Man (PS2) and Spider-Man 2 (PSP) played like the PS1 duology, it wasn't set in the same universe... lately I discovered something though, the PS1 original was ported to GBC, which got a sequel... and a 3rd installment, Mysterio's Menace.

When I finally looked at Mysterio's Menace it really took me by surprise, the graphics, UI, power ups... everything seemed like the PS1 duology, and that's because, from what I've read, this is a sequel to that, and not the GBC timeline, regardless if that's the case or not, it sure feels like it. I've just finished a playthrough on Easy and, while nowhere near the experience I got from the PS1 duology, it feels quite good, and it's worthy of the classics I grew up with, the 3rd installment I always wanted. Well then, what are you experiences with Spider-Man video games? I know there are lots of them, good and bad, a lot of memories we can talk about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542261
A little update. I still haven't been able to get everything in Spider-Man: Mysterio's Menace, the upgrades are a challenge to find, I've only got a couple so far, but it's fun to explore the levels while looking for these things. Anyway, I did just finish a playthrough on Normal difficulty, so Super Hero is all that remains, besides doing it 100% of course, though I won't be too harsh on myself if I don't pull it off, there are a few Spider-Man video games where I wanted 100% completion and gave up, like Spider-Man on PS1 due to the Quick-Change suit being impossible to get, and 8bit Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin for having 1 life.

I still have a smile on my face, as this feels like the 3rd installment to the PS1 duology that I've wanted through out my entire childhood, the graphics and UI are clearly based on it, it can't be a coincidence. Vicarious Visions did a good job here, just like they did in Spider-Man 2: Enter Electro, though neither is as good as Neversoft's original, and from the trilogy I'd say this is the worst one... I think Spider-Man can work well in 2D, but this feels like the 3D PS1 duology, just with a dimension less, so it's simply lesser by default, still good, but not as good. I do feel that this is a worthy ending to the series I loved on the PS1 though.

Of course there are things that bother me, Spider-Man really needed more invincibility frames after getting hit, and enemies can have life bars that are too large at times, or just have a very cheap placement overall, especially on the edge of platforms you have to jump on... either way, level design is still good and varied for the most part, interesting to navigate in and explore, I also love the controls, it doesn't feel as good as 16bit Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin to me, but it does feel good overall, and it's a good translation of the PS1 control scheme. Next is difficulty Super Hero, and 100% completion, hopefully I can pull it off soon.

Another update, I managed to get everything on Normal difficulty, 100% completion, now all that remains is doing it on Super Hero difficulty, though I don't plan on doing that now as I can see that it'll be quite a challenge and I'm not in the proper mindset to go for it, but hopefully in the future I will. Overall I loved revisiting all of the levels after defeating Mysterio, in an attempt to find everything, the upgrades and suits, and eventually I did. I loved how everything was hidden, they're not in plain sight, but with some exploration you'll eventually find them... except the Symbiote suit, I'm ashamed to admit that I had to use a guide for that.

While looking for everything I've missed during my first playthrough, doing some exploration, it made me appreciate how good the level design is, and I started to get so good at some levels that playing them felt exhilarating, the flow and rhythm really made me feel like Spider-Man... I have a few gripes with it though, Spider-Man really needed invincibility frames, as when you get surrounded by enemies it can be a chore, also having enemies on the edge of platforms can feel quite cheap. One last thing is the web slinging, it actually feels good... but you can't gain altitute from it, I really wish it was closer to Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin.

I'm glad I've finally played and completed Mysterio's Menace though, this is a worthy follow-up of the PS1 duology I grew up with, not as good as those due to the hardware and its limitation, especially due to the loss of a whole dimension, but Spider-Man can definitely work in 2D, and this is an example of that. Vicarious Visions did a good job here and I can't recommend it enough for those that grew up with all of Spider-Man's adventures on the PS1, it has the soul of the Spider-Man 3 that we never got for that console. I wish there were more suits, levels, set pieces, voice acting, moves, etc... but it's the GBA, not the PS!, so I understand.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I can think of two ancient video games that made me feel this way as a kid. First I literally have never thought about until now. Some dirty cheap floppy disk 8-bit dos looking poor man’s monkey island point and click adventure game. It was about a man going on holiday and he had to fly on cheap plane loaded with chickens. I remember feeling dread and disgust as a kid for no reason just because of how cheap it felt. I guess it was probably some obscure home brew game from the time.
The second was an Australian history edutainment game about the first fleet but you played as a convict. In the shop hold you could interact with things. There was a sick guy and when you examine him he had plague. If you stole his bible your character died of plague. In the hold there was this creepy early cgi eerie shadowed criminal who gaslighted and baited you into siding with him. If you let him corrupt you you kind of escape the guards but they eventually shoot you and kill you both. It dealt with my too much blood and death for something out of a scholastic magazine my teacher was trialing after hours at my small Christian school. Disgusting and dread inducing .
