Its two fundamentally different playstyles. JSR is closer to older skating games where skating was something you had to learn to control. Where as THPS just makes it easier to control since its meant to make you feel like an expert off the bat.
>>9529553
It is, but I found it really cozy in a way. Reminds me of urban exploration and finding big, empty areas that are long abandoned and dilapidated. The emptier JSRF spots are basically an elaborated versions of the outskirts of the JSR maps
Ultimately, JSR is a game taking place where the environment isn't built for skating; the skill comes in maximizing how well you can skate in environments actively working against you.
JSRF is a world built like a giant skate park. Both have their merits.

JSR gameflow
>the player learns the layout of the levels, where useful grinds and jumps are, where the sprays are, and learns how the police will move and how to avoid them
>player begins level and maps out how they'll hit the tags while keeping in mind the numbers of tags that will make harder enemies appear and keeping in mind strategies for luring away enemies or avoiding them
>player goes from tag to tag tricking as much as possible, stylishly flowing through the level following the guide they've set for themselves

JSRF gameflow
>go here and tag some stuff in this area and platform around

posts.com:
>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

Why DO all the characters in MK (visually) have the same normals anyway? In a game with traditional graphics they'd have characters with the same moves and similar outfits to save on labor by editing one character to create the other (draw a Ryu sprite then change the head and colors to make it Ken, many such cases). But in MK they weren't drawing anything, they were just filming actors on a blue screen, so they could have had them all do different moves and it wouldn't have been any more work. They threw away visual variety that they could have had for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

>>9525592
The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525706
Simply put, compiling takes source code/instructions written by humans, for humans, and translates/compiles it into something made to be interpreted by a machine.
For example, going from something like the C programming language, to potentially an intermediate representation (like assembly or something else), and ultimately always ends up as machine code.
So you have something high level that makes sense to a human like `print("hello")` boil down to many assembly instructions `mov x y; inc a; ...` down to even more machine instructions expressed as binary (usually rendered to humans as hex) `0x07; 0x6F; 0x32 ...`.

Decompiling is that process in reverse, and worse, it's lossy.
Documentation for the code, written as comments in the human readable source, can't be restored since it gets discarded during compilation (the machine doesn't need these, only humans do). Likewise with function and variable names (usually).
You have to read the opcodes for the machine (from the binary file) and try to deduce what could have produced that sequence of operations.
What function(s) could compile into this specific sequence?
Functions plural because multiple high level concepts can compile down to the same instructions, so even if you find an answer, it may not be the original answer.
Almost like an algebra problem, but worse. y + x = 7, what is x and y? 5 and 2? 4 and 3?

The only thing you can really do is get close approximations, and test them. Did my function compile to the same bytes? Does it "match"?

See also: https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2020/05/beyond-emulation-the-massive-effort-to-reverse-engineer-n64-source-code/

Just as with high level languages, you build up and accrue abstractions over time. I mean that both on a personal and project level. You also don't have a lot of the extra bullshit to deal with like an OS or VMM so you can greatly reduce and simplify what you even need to build and deal with in the first place. You write what you want, how you want to , with the only limits being the target machine itself.
Consider something as simple as loading data from a constant address versus making multiple syscalls to deal with some general purpose file system.

When somebody speaks about "source code", they usually mean code coming from a dev that is cleanly written in a way that other humans with programming knowledge can understand, this makes it much more easy to modify for hacks, ports and what not.

Yes, there are tools to partially or completely see the code from a ROM, the problem is said code looks like an unintelligible mess since it doesn't keep any comments or the given names for variables, functions, etc. Some hackers can work with that mess and slowly figure out what is what by trial and error, the end result would be something very close to the official dev source code, but it takes too much time, guess work and autism, and there's still a chance for inaccuracies, therefore, having the official code from a dev is always more convenient than try to reverse engineer it yourself, unfortunately since it has to come from an official source and may be illegal to share, it's very rare for one to come out, so it's a big deal when one does get released. At least if it's from a game people give a shit about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9546085
Depends on the type of memory used and general storing conditions such as humidity, temperature, UV exposure etc.
SNES uses almost entirely MaskRom (there is a full list of variants on snescentral), which lasts a lot longer than the cheap Flash Memory some 3DS games in Europe used, which started failing earlier than their supposed 10-15 year lifetime. I'd expect SNES failure rates to increase around the 40-50year range.
Now keep in mind, this type of tech is relatively easy to maintain if you're not a retard. ROM can be replaced, same with the fat tracks on a delaminated circuit board and connectors refurbished. Leaking batteries could totally fuck the whole thing. Still, if you want your plastic shell and label could potentially outlive you.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9540607
People remember how HUGE Banjo Kazooie was in the summer of 1998. But people forget that Ocarina of Time made people slowly forget about the bear and bird. Then Donkey Kong 64 came out and there were tons of collectathons so when Banjo Tooie came out people were tired of collectathons not to mention in the holiday christmas season of 2000 the N64 was now considered old, the PS2 had come out and took all the thunder away. Banjo Tooie was never as popular as the first game which in gaming it's a bad sign. They could've turned it around with a great third Banjo game on Gamecube and establish Banjo as a franchise but Rare was sold and didn't get a new game until the IP was dead.
Microsoft didn't want to lose the work that had already been done so they released the GBA Banjo game. But by the time the game came out many Nintendo fans had moved on from Rare, not to mention it didn't get much advertisement from THQ who published the game and of course Nintendo weren't going to do their own marketing for a competitors mascot and use their Game Boy to promote the Xbox. The spin-off sounding game doesn't help it either. The game is actually really good, as good as a Banjo game could've been on GBA doomed by its circumstances.
Had Nintendo never sold Rare it would've gotten the marketing it deserved and the hype for Banjo Threeie would've helped Banjo become an actual franchise and the GBA game would've sold well and be remembered.

Banjo Pilot failed because as I mentioned above Banjo never became an established IP. When you took Donkey Kong out of the game it was just another generic kart racing game on the GBA which already had plenty of and everyone had already gotten their fix with Konami Krazy Racers for a mario kart clone until Mario Kart came out. When Banjo came out it was just a generic clone without anything special and an IP that had died. Even if Rare had not been sold or if it had kept the Donkey Kong License, the Banjo/DK Pilot game would've failed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Looking more like a weird piece of office equipment than a game console, the RCA Studio II fell victim to bad timing. It was developed and planned for a 1975 launch date but a change in RCA management during this time pushed it back to an early 1977 release. The Studio II's black and white graphics looked inferior to the Fairchild Channel F which displayed in color, and the Atari VCS's launch later in the year made it look even cruder. It was discontinued in early 1978 and an estimated between 57,000 and 64,000 units sold. This would make it the smallest-selling game console ever sold in North America. The decision to pull the plug came after the Studio II failed to sell much over the 1977 holiday season and the realization that it had no hope to compete with the VCS. The Charlotte, North Carolina plant where the Studio II was manufactured was closed and 120 workers laid off.

The Studio II used RCA's 1802, the first microprocessor fabricated in CMOS, and a custom graphics chip known as "Pixie" which displayed 64x32 block graphics. There were 512 bytes of RAM, split 50/50 between video and work RAM. It used ROM cartridges but included five built-in games as well. Just ten cartridges were produced, with a possible 11th (Bingo, a suspected prototype or planned but never actually shipped).

RCA engineer Joe Weisbecker was the main designer of the Studio II and his high school-aged daughter Janice programmed two games for it, Schoolhouse and Speedway/Tag. This would make her the first female game designer/programmer in video game history.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Sell to gamestop/local used videogame store.
Sell on craigslist/local bulletin board and meet somewhere public with a friend.
Sell on ebay.
In order of low risk to high risk, and low reward to high reward. Your local store will give you the least amount of money, but it will be cash-in-hand with no fuckery. Trying to sell online but outside the ebay ecosystem is dealing with a constant stream of scammers trying to low-ball you with very few if any real offers, and nobody wants to pay market value. Selling on ebay is running the risk of having the buyer scam you and keeping the game and the money, or sending you a fake back and ebay ignores you when you say they switched the item on you, but if you do manage to sell you'll likely get current market value or better.
Let's get real. If you need to turn to 4chan to ask for advice on selling items, you will be doing option #1, like nearly everyone else.

posts.com:
Dungeon Keeper 1's open source port, KeeperFX, has recently completed it's source code rewrite.

KeeperFX has been around for many years but it was always only a partial rewrite, reading a lot of the game code from the original game (turned into a .dll file). But now all of the functions have finally been rewritten so the .dll is no longer required and the source code is free from a lot of limitations.

There's also been a high FPS update, DK1 was previously locked to 20FPS. Further view distance in possession, zoom out, plus a lot of little quality of life improvements.

Larger map sizes and multiplayer improvements are currently being worked on.

Source code: https://github.com/dkfans/keeperfx
Download KeeperFX: https://keeperklan.com/threads/7427-KeeperFX-0-5-0
Latest KeeperFX patch: https://keeperklan.com/threads/7429?p=58263
New map editor: https://rainlizard.itch.io/unearth

posts.sub: Maximo - Ghosts to Glory and Vs. Army of Zin
posts.com:
Just finished playing these two games and wanted to talk about them.

Starting with Ghosts to Glory. The ability system is noteworthy, for experienced players, it rewards mastery over the game, making Maximo super powerful if you are skilled enough to stay alive, while providing new players 3 permanent slots (or up to 6 later) so that they can keep their favorite abilities if they die. I do think there are 2 problems, the game does a poor job at explaining the system, I had a hard time figuring how it works initially, and that you can't unequip an ability once you get it.

The abilities keep the otherwise simple moveset from becoming boring, it also helps that the enemies die easily and are hard-hitting, leading to a nice pace of combat that 3D action games don't often have, giving the game an arcadey feel. One aspect I don't like is collecting souls, after a while it gets repetitive and boring, and it stops the otherwise great flow of gameplay.

I also really like the enemy design, some requires low attacks, attacks from above or behind to be taken out, it helps create the flow I talked about, making it a bit more strategic and making positioning during a fight more important. While individually they may be easy to kill, put different types of them together and you have a really hard game. However, most of the bosses aren't that great, they are pretty easy and the solution often trivial and effortless to find out, the king was the best fight, while the last boss was a huge disappointment.

Another system that is really cool once fully understood is the saving system, having to pay 100 koins to save is a neat idea, you are always spending your koins, buying things like armor, shield or health in a level when in a bind, so money is always a precious resource you want to keep. Having to pay 100 koins to go between levels also helps prevent players farming coins in easier levels.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Army of Zin had drastical changes to gameplay, resembling more closely to Devil May Cry. While that's not what I wanted out of the sequel, it's still a good game.

There are some direct improvements to this title, mainly the camera. Which you can now control with the left stick, or the R1 button like GtG (that can be readjusted while moving, thank god). One aspect that I do miss and one of my favorite stylistic choices is the angled camera in the first game, RIP. Also, having enemies drop souls instead was a great choice.

Gameplay wise the excellent ability system is now gone and replaced with a fine but unremarkable (and abuseable to grinding) shop system where you can buy them instead, they aren't as varied or overpowered since they are permanent, but the new weapon and combo attacks is what keeps the gameplay fresh instead. Overall, stringing attack combos on enemies is fun and I like the playstyle the hammer brings, the ice upgrade made it way more fun, freezing low priority targets to focus on the high priority ones with the sword.

My biggest gripe is how lacking the enemy design is in this game, despite some of them being more complex than the enemies in GtG, they are more unsatisfying to fight. The quantity of enemies increased and they are much tankier, leading to prolonged fights, often done in a certain area, before moving on to the next one, in contrast to GtG where fights were more spread out and done while platforming through the level. What really bothers me is how enemies are used. For the majority of the game, the same types of enemies are used together, which leads the player to use the same strategy everytime. I say majority because the first area of the game was great, it had different types of enemies, with different weakness that made fights interesting and varied.
However, I do love the bosses. They are way harder with diverse movesets and gimmicks, and the animations are amazing.

So, /vr/ what did you guys think of these games?

Duke Nukem 3D has a bunch of that scattered here and there, not everywhere, but there's lots of real life things which are there just for detail.

>plenty of rooms throughout the game have light switches for turning the lights on or off, the lights themselves can also be destroyed at times
>electric wall outlets which you can crouch down to poke for 1 damage, just because
>offices with phones, computers, telephones, paperwork, coffee cups and donuts, swivel chairs, coffee machines, stacks of single use cups, bookshelves, clocks on the wall, potted plants, etc
>bars and clubs/stripclubs with, well, bars, bottles of beer and booze, drinking glasses, jars of pickles, cash registers, bar stools, wine racks, etc, even a working(ish) pool table

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9547575
>What are some essential addons and mods other than recapping?
ram expansion is a must. 1mb of chip ram doesn't last long. recapping is a must because they're really awful. IDE hard drive -> memory card reader is a must if you want internal storage. if you want to play games, then get a hxc floppy emulator and look for whdload games that can be run from a hard disk.

>>9547578
amiga is retro. kys.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First thing to check is which Kickstart rom version you have. Early ones lack internal ide driver, a replacement with a Kickstart 3.1 will allow you to use a more up to date OS.
To use WHDLoad, extra ram is recommended. I extended mine to 2Mo Chip ram (usable for gfx) and 8 Mo Fast ram (system ram) if you don't car for AGA or 3D games it's enough.
Otherwise you'll have to look for an accelerator card or even A600 Vampire for AGA.
A 4 to 8 Gb Compact flash instead of an harddrive, you'll need a cf to ide adaptator. There is some especially designed for amiga to allow cf to be accessible from outside or still have an ide connector if needed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You need a joystick or controller. Megadrive pad works out of the box but used as is there is a risk to fry some chip in the Amiga. There is an adapter to avoid that or you can mod a MD pad.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Only as exemple, there is a wealth of sellers of new amiga parts.
https://www.retropassion.co.uk/product/amiga-a600-1mb-chip-ram-upgrade-total-2mb/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Mostly already said but you want:
RAM Expansion
Compact Flash card with ide adapter
CD32 joypad
Possibly Floppy emulator
The best way to play Amiga games is via WHDLoad, as it a) it makes everything load close to instantly as it's off hard drive b) they added in loads of quality of life fixes so with a CD32 joypad there's no more up to jump or using keyboard for extra buttons in those kind of games.
You WILL need a joystick, you can get away with a keyboard for some games, but plenty won't work with only a keyboard, or won't work well. Megadrive pads are dangerous and in the long run will break your machine.
You can get most of the parts above (and kickstart ROMs) off of Ebay for cheap.

>The Longest Journey was developed by a small internal team at Funcom led by Ragnar Tørnquist. It was their first original project. Funcom put few restrictions on the developers except the budget (approx. $2–3 million) and the deadline. Since the team had to develop the game engine and most of the required tools from scratch, they struggled to release the game on time. For most of 1999, the team had to work overtime and during weekends to ultimately meet the deadline. In the original Norwegian release, April Ryan was voiced by the journalist Synnøve Svabø.
>Funcom Oslo AS (OSE: FUNCOM, formerly Funcom Productions AS) is a Norwegian video game developer that specializes in online games. It is best known for the massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) titles Conan Exiles, Age of Conan, Anarchy Online, The Secret World – and The Longest Journey series of adventure games. The company has offices in Oslo, Norway; North Carolina, US; Lisbon, Portugal; Bucharest, Romania; and Stockholm, Sweden. It also had offices in Beijing, Dublin, and Montreal previously. It is now owned by the Chinese media conglomerate Tencent.

>>9547684
>>9548609
Every state for a character has an internal active name, whenever you wavedash the game itself recognizes it as the “waveland” state. You can see this in the 20xx or training mode mods where you can get the code to display in-game.

Every wavedash also has 10 frames of landing lag for every character, something completely unique to this specific type of landing and specifically written in the game’s code for this exact state.

The “wavedashing is a glitch” thing is a complete myth.

ITT: Add a single feature or make a single change that would drastically improve the quality of a video game of your choice.

I'll start with a few of mine...

1. TECMO World Cup Soccer (NES): A button that switches which player you're controlling in defence. When you lose the ball, it's common for AI defenders to attempt a tackle in a completely wrong manner, while you're stuck with a player just chasing the opponent with the ball, being able to control a defender in a better position is ideal.

2. Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters (GB) & Yu-Gi-Oh! Dark Duel Stories (GBC): I'd say both of these have an issue that plagues most of the franchise, and that is if you're going for something like 100% completion, or simply going after a few specific cards... the drop rates are a pain. A store where you can buy specific cards for some currency is best.

3. Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin (MS/GG) & Spider-Man/X-men in Arcade's Revenge (MD/SNES): A couple of Marvel adaptations here, mostly focused on Spider-Man, and both have the same issue, getting sent back the whole way after dying too much, which you will. An actual lives system in the former, and unlimited continues in the latter.

Well, those are just some changes I'd make. I know many would too, for tons of other video games, so voice them here, anons!

>>9546665
Mario Sunshine doesn't really work like 64 did where there's multiple objectives per one stage entrance. Every episode you enter has different parts swapped around and the episodes progress in a way that tells a small story about each level's inhabitants as you make your way through the level. For example, there are tourists at Sirena Beach that grow increasingly frustrated with the hotel's customer service as the levels progress, and there's a yellow pianta in Ricco Harbor that has a different excuse for shirking his work every episode with one exception where he hints at a hidden blue coin in the wall near him. Sunshine's episode structure enhances the worldbuilding which is something Sunshine focuses on a lot so to compromise that would detract from one of the game's best aspects. The things I would fix with Sunshine is make every episode in the game have 100 coins in it so you can get that shine in any episode and having skippable cutscenes. The big thing I would change is the progression system, though this is much more than the thread asks. I'd make the shadow mario fights their own special encounters that appear after a certain number of shines so progression is tied to shine quantity rather than completing specific objectives. Ideally, Shadow Mario would work similarly to Galaxy's comet stars where after a certain # of shines collected, Shadow Mario appears in a level where defeating him yields a shine and progresses the story. 7 fights at 10 shine intervals for a total of 70 to unlock every fight and 78 to beat the game since shadow mario fights and final bowser give shines. The dark veil over delfino plaza goes away at 60 shines but you only need 58 to beat the game regularly so if you do the bare minimum one of the game's biggest problems goes unsolved, so by upping the requirement to 70 to beat the game makes sure all the bad stuff Bowser Jr. did to pollute the island gets fixed. Sorry for the autistic rant. SMS is literally my favorite game.

As a 5~6 year old, there were a few stars I never managed to get... but I felt satisfied that I'd beat the game when I beat Bowser in the final boss fight and watched the credits, I was hype enough about it then that I recorded it on VHS (I still have it).
When I went back as a teenager and 100%ed the entire game I appreciated the added bonus content for doing it, but I feel like the game is made to feel satisfying for either style of play: players who don't like grinding and//or or players who get hardcore filtered by certain stars. If there were fewer to obtain I'd actually feel cheated. I like the game enough I enjoy striving for every single star every playthrough, even the "get 100 coins" ones everybody seems to hate.

>Too bad there will never be a multicart esque arcade machine you can load roms off of
It's possible to set up a cabinet that has multiple arcade flash-carts installed.

You could get Neo Geo, CPS1/2, Naomi, Atomiswave, PGM1/2 all set up on the same cabinet running on original hardware + flash memory modules + netboot/ODE and switch between them via video switcher. Would be a lot of money and wire work but it absolutely could be done. Throw a PS2 in the mix for system 11,12, and 256 ports running on semi-native hardware.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9540219
Yes, I've played the arcade version.

I'll clarify for you: Carnevil used a gun I/O board. That's a common thing light gun arcade games have that basically translates what the light gun sees into coordinates that the main board can use. Home consoles, even ones that are EXTREMELY similar to the arcade version like the Sega NAOMI/Dreamcast, obviously can't just plug the arcade's gun I/O board into its controller sockets and make it work. The N64 console would have to already have a working light gun made for it (or I suppose Midway could have made one exclusively for Carnevil, but I can't imagine it would have been profitable). There WAS an N64 light gun in development early on in its lifespan, but it got canceled for whatever reason.

In other words, the Midway Seattle's games being possible to port to the N64 has absolutely nothing to do with whether the N64 had light gun support.

>>9527356
>don't think I've ever seen a source for that but I've read it in other places. I don't know where the rumor comes from or if it's true.
Right, but it's definitely an idea that's been going around online, true or not. It's a small form of vindication for me at any rate, even finding out that it's definitely untrue would be interesting enough for me.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

>If it were a normal linear beltscroller it wouldn't stand out so much

Maybe, but I'd argue that on top of all the gimmicks, it has pretty damn good fundamentals. Real good hits and feedback, solid enemy roster with just enough variety, combos feel good, and there's some moderate nuances to the system like being able to stagger combos.

It's a rock solid meat and potatoes game on top of having all those unique and fun time attack gimmicks AND having the trademark body horror set pieces and wild occult lovecraftian slasher aesthetic. So yeah I think it deserves a lot of praise as a beltscroller.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536428
It isn't complex, no, but there's an appeal in that in itself, Doom is better than Wolfenstein 3D, because the latter is very plain in comparison, but there's a certain fun purity in it too which works (and there's actually a little bit more depth to Wolf3D than people give it credit for). Compare also to how Super Mario Bros. 3 is categorically better than the first Super Mario Bros. and has way more depth, with far more content of greater variety, but it's still fun to play the first one anyway.

If you look at Splatterhouse and think that it should have more complexity to it, then what you'd be looking at is Splatterhouse 3, which has a little bit more gameplay depth, and which also actually has multiple endings. The western release has those endings hanging on really a very strict time limit, so it's actually pretty hard to get the best ending, but the Japanese one is essentially the same (down to being in English), but with a far less harsh timer. Opinions are divisive in the fandom about a lot of things, but there's many who think the third Splatterhouse is the best one, while some dislike how it deviates from the simpler style of the previous games.

There's also the infamous reboot, which isn't really retro (I guess it's sort of a remake, but not really?). Tastes are divided on that one as well, but there's a lot of people who think that while it's indeed rather flawed, the game is actually pretty decent for what it is, and works well enough with the property.

There's also one other significant change in the English version, which I think is much more damning: the invincible spin kick move is a typical belt-scroller style "exchange hp for an invincible reversal" style move in the Japanese version...but in English they gave it a trickier input but in exchange made it totally invincible and costs no HP. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536624
I love the atmosphere throughout, but Splatterhouse was always quite in your face with the gore, that was the point. I think that the gore is actually rather impressive for the hardware they were working with, mainly to get viscera that good and detailed on a TurboGfx-16 and Sega Genesis, with equally disgusting monster design.
From the arcade game in 1988, to Splatterhouse 3 in August 1993, I can't think of any remotely popular videogame available in the west which has this quality of gore and in these quantities. The only rival is Doom, which is fantastic (especially in that regard), but wouldn't be on the market until December of 1993, and was working with far more permissive memory and color palettes.

Actually, I suppose those Elvira games were quite gory, and about the horror, though they were some sort of adventure games, as opposed to Splatterhouse and Doom being realtime action games, so I guess I could attach that qualifier.

>>9536654
I think that there was no change in the content itself between the Japanese version and the two international versions. They differ slightly, but I think it's little code tweaks/fixes.
There was changes during development of all sorts of kinds (the devs mentioned that the blood used to be red before Namco had them changed to green, for instance), but that was before it made it onto the Japanese market itself. There's some leftover stuff in the release versions, but I'm not sure if it was left out for censorship reasons, as much as things which they cut because they thought didn't fit or was good enough, or because of hardware limitations or not having the time to refine it to the point that they liked.
https://tcrf.net/Splatterhouse_(Arcade)

I think the first one is just a bit hard to get into and not quite as...expansive? as some of its contemporaries.

On the former point, while memorization and trial and error are blatant in a lot of games of the time (though not as much as some people think IMO), some of the stuff in the game just feels annoying to lose a credit too (poltergeist room in particular comes to mind, Biggyman too if you don't know how to beat him with slides or the double shotgun cheese).

When I say expansive...what I mean is like, comparing the gameplay to say Castlevania 1 (odd comparison I know, but it's one of the only classics I can think of which has a similar level of commitment in its movement and attacks) and I feel like there's just a lot more going on in that game in terms of enemy patterns, platforming, secondary systems like sub weapons, etc. at least IMO

Not trying to shit on the game mind you. It's far from a kusoge or anything, it's very functional, plays smooth, and has some great segments and stages. But it's gameplay is a bit stiff and limited IMO. Maybe I'll revisit it today.

posts.com:
>>9545790
You have no business acumen, so let me teach you a few things. First of all, those consoles like the MTV and IBM versions, those are licensed. That means those companies had to pay royalties for having their logo displayed. Right there, that's money being made before the hardware even sells. Secondly, limited run hardware is generally expected to sell out because it commands a higher demand and incentivizes more preorders -- so it's a great way to establish a profit baseline for a fiscal quarter earnings report. Also, it isn't uncommon for companies to produce a run of say, 20k units, only to hold back or repurchase a small portion of that stock with the intention of listing it on sites like eBay under an anonymous account at an inflated price; letting them clean up extra cash on the "secondhand" market with the stock they would normally offer at MSRP, all without damaging PR. You also have to take into account that this stuff is very cheap to produce; most of these "special" editions are nothing more than a printed logo or a swapped jewel, so they're losing very little by doing this. More than anything, it's just a way to offer variety to customers; maybe somebody really, really likes that Metroid Prime or RE4 edition and purchases the console when they otherwise wouldn't have. I hope you learned something today. Please never make a thread this fucking retarded ever again.

As the tech becomes cheaper and more readily available to the average consumer, VR gaming is going to explode.

It took me a moment to get the joke. That TV really was made by Admiral. By the looks of it, the manufacturing date is 1994? Considering that it is Coaxial only (not unusual for a 20inch NTSC screen) , it probably was a really cheap TV set back in the day. It doesn't even have RCA cables.

>>9541996
>Where is the SCART port lol

Sadly SCART never existed on NTSC-U TV's. At some point in the early 90's TV's started adding S-Video in models that were 25inch or larger. S-Video still doesn't look comparable to SCART. In later 90's NTSC TV's from 1997 and onwards, component was added. But, at that point, we were getting closer to HDTV's being a reality.
